author: @mstrhz6078

author: @TaylanMorcol
text: Hi Dr. Josh, I'm curious to get your thoughts on a simulation I'm running. It's very similar to the simulation in this video where you calculate 10,000 p-values by sampling from the same distribution.   When I run my simulation using a Welch t-test and n=3, only ~3.5% of p-values are less than 0.05. The percentage converges on 5% when I increase the sample size or use the Student's t-test.   It seems as though forgoing the equal variances assumption sacrifices some power, especially at low sample sizes. But I'm still trying to grasp why that is and what the implications are for using the Welch t-test with low sample size in real-life situations. For example, if the null hypothesis is that both samples come from the same population, then why not just assume equal variances and use Student's t-test all the time? (I know that last question is probably conflating some concepts that should be separate, but I'm having a hard time keeping track of it all, and I'm really interested to hear how you would respond to that question).  You seem to have a great way of explaining things like this intuitively. I'm curious to hear your thoughts.  Thanks so much! I've benefited greatly from your videos.

author: @DavidAlexanderDickie
text: Just adding my two (pernickety) pence Josh. The original 1995 BH method defined a new threshold and didn't actually adjust the P-values. author: @ohbennyboy
text: Hi, I don't understand (@17:07). The adjusted first p-value (0.1 - no longer significant) is independent to all the previous p-values and is only dependent on the number of genes. Your example shows one "false positive" and the rest are not significant, yet the result would be exactly the same even if all the other values are below 0.05. This is because you're calculation is independent of the other p-values. So really, explaining the calculations for p-values ranked 2-10 is redundant, the adjusted p-value will almost always be greater than 0.05.  In an example of proteomics where there are 3500 proteins analysed, to consider a p-value really significant according to your FDR principle, the p-values which could be considered true positives would have to be 0.000014 or lower.  Obviously that's silly. As there would be a large amount of false positives, only accepting values of 0.000014 or lower would exclude many true positives also.  A reply would be much appreciated.

author: @RobertWF42
text: Cool, thanks for posting this, very intuitive! An equivalent¬†method for eyeballing the # of true null hypotheses is to plot ranked 1 - p-value on the x-axis and the hypothesis test rank on the y-axis, then fit a line to the scatter plot, starting at the origin. Where the line hits the y-axis is your estimate of the # of true null hypotheses.Would like to see an intuitive explanation for the Benjamini‚ÄìYekutieli procedure, used in studies where the tests are not completely independent!

author: @malisasmith5928
text: Hi, this video helped me a lot! But I am still confused about the intuition behind the algorithm.   Benjamini-Hochberg will find that the samples with the lowest p-values are significant after adjustment. But doesn't Bonferroni do that as well? What exactly about the rank-based BH algorithm makes it specifically control the FDR and take into account the proportion of p < 0.05 which are thought to come from the uniform distribution? I imagine that it is more sophisticated than simply a smaller multiplier.  Some thoughts: The highest p-value is assigned rank N. This p-value is not adjusted at all, to p*N/N = p. This seems fine and shouldn't change the FDR ratio if it's already above 0.05. The lowest p-value is assigned rank 1. This p-value is adjusted a lot, to potentially p*N/1. At this point it seems similar to Bonferroni. I don't fully understand what's going on here.  Thanks again for the help!

I wish to adjust the p-values to weed out any false positives.  When I rank the p-values, can I simply choose all p-values in the "< 0.05 bin" of the observed distribution?  That kind of mimics what you did in the first example starting @ 14.47.  But in the second example @ 17:07, how did you actually compute the adjust p-vales?  Did you just repeat the method on the blue boxes (observed) and on the red boxes (null) separately?  Thanks, and keep up the great videos!
